string.text: Usek sits at the foot of the Akkan hills on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.

Tihr was once a fishing settlement of the Jumne, where settlers aimed for Rovalatys would come ashore. For some time, it was under the yoke of the Winlunding, whose migrations overwhelmed the Calradoi occupation. Nevertheless, some Jumne population already existed within the Ebor peninsula, and both populations were able to cohabitate. Yet, once the Jumne started another mass migration of their own, Tihr was taken from the Wilunding, and expanded into a great port of its own - the main destination for northern settlers to arrive in the continent. Today, the northern Ebor and most of the Bay of Sargot is controlled by Jumne chieftains.

Loukis sits by a flat plain next to Pilislinn. These plains were among the first lands to be colonized by the Lokti, after their migration from the east. Wheat is fruitful here, and the grain allowed Pilislinn to thrive into the capital it is.

High on the Lokti mountains, folks at Avis-Uolinis raise sheep, to feed and clothe the freemen of Pilislinn. The sheep, a local breed, thrive on the grassy, rocky slopes of the mountain range, if not for the wolves and leopards.

Zholes is a solitary settlement of the Lokti, far west of the Lokti mountain range. The gentle curves of the soil make it unproductive for farming, but the vast sea of grasses allow northern steeds to thrive during the snow-free months.
Manbat lies within the dark pine forests of the Lokti. Villagers here hunt in the Vakken tradition, experts of the northern forests.
Kalnis was one of the first Lokti settlements since their migration from the east. The city lies on a naturally fortified position, with mountain streams and green fields to nurture its population.
Kvieshi is a Lokti settlement where villagers grow and harvest wheat during the summer to sell at Kalnis. The harsh temperatures and eastern winds make growing impossible during the winter.
Purvis lies at the base of the Lokti mountains. Mountain streams gather here into a marshy and muddy soil, making it good for flax growth.
Kárvis
Kárvis lies at the southern edges of the Lokti flatlands, where the green pastures meet the dry steppes. Villagers here raise steppe cattle for milk and meat during the winter.
Raubat is a mining settlement of the Lokti. The village lies on the mountain slopes, where the Lokti found iron within the rock, essential fuel to the daily economy of their towns.

Mishkalinn is a fortified settlement by one of the forested valley near the Lokti mountains. Tales tell it was once a Vakken forest-fort. Nevertheless, it is today fully assimilated into the Lokti realm, who have blood ties to the Vakken, but follow their own ways.
Kylamishka is a Lokti settlement deep in a forested valley. Villagers here are descendants of the Vakken to the south.
Purvis lies on the edge of the Lokti forest. Here the humidity gathers in a bog, which combined with the flat soil makes it fruitful to grow flax.

Sendnar, once a Jumne settlement, sits by the northernmost shores of the continent, at the origins of the Byalic peninsula. Named after the black sands of its cliffs, Sendnar is now populated by the Lokti, who settled in the nearby mountains. Trade relations with the Jumne are still maintained, though most Jumne settlers these days ignore the Lokti shores, in favor of the warmer Calradian shores to the west.
Hákarlar
Hákarlar sits by the northernmost shores of the continent and at the origins of the Byalic peninsula. It was once a Jumne community of fishers, whose trade also involved whales and sharks.

Sargot is a common name for hills, promontories, islands and other defensible positions in western Calradia. It refers to a fortified encampment of the Massa, a tribe allied to the the Vlandians who joined their invasion. Though the Massa moved on, their stay was often so traumatic for a district that the name remained long after their departure. This Sargot was actually founded on the ruins of an imperial town, resettled by Vlandians, and which has supplanted the memory of the community that came before it.
Poncta Bisco

Lavenia is a fishing village on the northeastern shores of the Perassic Sea. The nearby castle guards one of the main passages over the network of lakes and salt lagoons known as the Calsea, one of the gateways to Aserai lands.
Praja Salga
Cerro Gaado
Vineas d'Illa
Atfarida-Ansaus catches fish between Xarakut and Gothau’h. Traditions says it was here where the Massa first landed, finding their divinely promised land to settle on.
A Massa settlement, folks at Triweinis collect wood for Xarakut. Though wood is plentiful, most of it is not adequate for walls or longships, and instead only wastes away their time and axes.

Stadeis lies on a clearing near Triwandeis. The gentle slopes allow raising horses, and the distance to the woods keep beasts away. Horsemanship is a typical tradition of most Wilunding peoples, including the Massa.
Gothau’h
Atisk is a farming settlement of the Massa, growing crops on one of the few large open plains of the peninsula, otherwise covered by thick and dangerous rainforest.
Araaran was a small settlement of locals, until the Massa moved in with their families. Villagers raise sheep by the hills, relatively safe from the rainforest predators.

Eisarn-Bairgahein sits in the mountain valley east to Gothau’h. Here an abundant iron vein is used by the Massa for their weapons, tools, wagons and ships. Mostly covered by flat, wooded fields, iron is otherwise scarce and valuable in the Ansiwe Fragifts peninsula.

Triwandiuza is the deepest Massa settlement within the rainforest. Settlers here learned from the Widugauja how to hunt down the forest beasts. Such exotic pelts and feathers fetch high prices in the Perassic markets.
Mathl-Fiskans lies by the southern shores of the Ansiwe Fragifts peninsula, near Xarakut. The warm waters have abundant fish of many kinds, many of which the Massa had never seen.
Tweihnai-Triweinana sits between patches of wood on the slopes near Xarakut. The Massa here collect the abundant wood, essential to their livelihoods.

Widusweina lies by the treeline near Xarakut. Here the Massa brought the Wilunding tradition of raising pigs, who thrive on the abundant foliage and fruit of the rainforest, if not for the beasts that hunt them down.

Swammos lies in a clearing within the woods near Xarakut. The water collects here into a bog, making the land fruitful for flax. Artisans at Xarakut process it into linen to be worn throughout the Massa realm.
Hórstathr

Tihr was once a fishing settlement of the Jumne, where settlers aimed for Rovalatys would come ashore. For some time, it was under the yoke of the Winlunding, whose migrations overwhelmed the Calradoi occupation. Nevertheless, some Jumne population already existed within the Ebor peninsula, and both populations were able to cohabitate. Yet, once the Jumne started another mass migration of their own, Tihr was taken from the Wilunding, and expanded into a great port of its own - the main destination for northern settlers to arrive in the continent. Today, the northern Ebor and most of the Bay of Sargot is controlled by Jumne chieftains.
Sautharauk lies on the core of the Byal peninsula, in a heat pocket protected from the northern winds. The Jumne raise sheep by the rock faces here, selling their wool, milk and meat at Hórstathr.
Grónnvollr

Grónnvollr lies on the core of the Byal peninsula, in a heat pocket protected from the northern winds. The plain fields here, exempt of permafrost, allowed the Jumne to grow and sow wheat, a very desirable ability within the north. This grain allows Hórstathr to exert power over the peninsula.
Járnar
Járnar lies west of Hórstathr, in the high plateaus of the Byal peninsula. The Jumne here found an iron vein, common in the mineral richy, rocky peninsula.
Fúna

Fúna lies on the core of the Byal peninsula, in a heat pocket protected from the northern winds. Villagers hunt foxes, wolves and deer for their elegant furs, much sought after by the traders that come from the south.
Svartavitha lies on the core of the Byal peninsula, in a heat pocket protected from the northern winds. The Jumne collect pine from the black forest, necessary to build and heaten their homes.

Byalakort is an Jumne colony in the southern edges of the Byal peninsula. Though the terrain is rocky and cold, the hardy Jumne still prevail, living off fishing and herding. Folks often cross the Byalic sea and climb up towards Sibir for trading.

Sauthavollr lies on the plateau of Hraukr, the High Rock. The Jumne raise sheep, naturally adapted to the rocky terrain. No part of the sheep are left unused: wool, meat and milk are harvested, for the cold peninsula is unforgiving.
Fjávollr

Fjávollr lies on the plateau of Hraukr, the High Rock. The Jumne raise their hardy northern cattle here, which feeds on the grasses of the plateau during its long summer. During winter, some of the cattle will be slaughtered for meat and to preserve hay.

Byalakort is an Jumne colony in the southern edges of the Byal peninsula. Though the terrain is rocky and cold, the hardy Jumne still prevail, living off fishing and herding. Folks often cross the Byalic sea and climb up towards Sibir for trading.
Vík

Vík is where the Jumne first landed on the southern Byal shores. Experts in fishing, they first settled here before moving inland. At times, villagers also catch whales that drift into the Byal sea, providing Byalakort with whale oil.
Ullbjarg lies north of Byalakort, on the heights of the Byal peninsula. Jumne colonists herd sheep on the hard yet grassy, uneven terrain, providing the town with both food and wool.
Lágrbjarg
Lágrbjarg at the bottom of the southern Byalic cliffs. In the forests here, the Jumne found an iron vein deep within the rock, which they use to forge their weapons and tools.
Tirby sits in the cold misty waters that lie off of the Ebor peninsula. The low-lying lands on the northern side of the Ebor are suited to the growing of flax.

Sirindac lies beneath the high ridges of the Ebor peninsula, somewhat sheltered from the bitter winds blowing out of the northwest. Migrants come here from across the Vlandian lands to prospect for silver in the mountain streams.

Tihr was once a fishing settlement of the Jumne, where settlers aimed for Rovalatys would come ashore. For some time, it was under the yoke of the Winlunding, whose migrations overwhelmed the Calradoi occupation. Nevertheless, some Jumne population already existed within the Ebor peninsula, and both populations were able to cohabitate. Yet, once the Jumne started another mass migration of their own, Tihr was taken from the Wilunding, and expanded into a great port of its own - the main destination for northern settlers to arrive in the continent. Today, the northern Ebor and most of the Bay of Sargot is controlled by Jumne chieftains.
Haen is today an Junme settlement. They collect timber for the construction of longships at Tihr, essential to the Junme trade and warfare.

Kohaga was built by the Wilunding, but then colonized by the Jumne, and sits on the edge of the Ebor peninsula. Villagers here raise hardy northern cattle, brought by the Junme longships. Such northern Calradian pastures seem warm in comparison to their own.

Ab Comer sits on the steep pass cut by the upper Trand river that climbs the Uchalion plateau. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Kurava is a forest fort of the Vakken, situated in the heart of the Ircaran wildlands. The nearby woods are populated by Vakken folk, while the plains are mixed in with the Sturgiske. In their tongue, Kurava stands for 'muddy', alluding to the humid terrain around the Miron river and the streams running down the Ircaran stony hills.

Irkaraa sits in a broaded forested valley looking down on the Galcha river. The villagers, the Vakken, in these parts are expert trappers, hunting marten, fox and rabbit for the rich pelts much in demand in the south. The region, Ircaran wildlands, is named after this ancient Vakken settlement.

Bakeko lies next to the Miron river, on the slopes of the river source. Bakeko, meaning a Sturgiske ship, is named after the river ships carrying the locally produced iron towards trade hubs such as Epicrotea. The settlement was first founded by Sturgiske colonists, who were allowed to explore the Ircaran lands in an alliance between the Sturgiske and the chieftain of Kurava.

Robatch lies on a clearing within the Ircaran wildlands. Here colonists cut down trees and planted grain instead, fruitful in the flat terrain blessed with streams from the hills. The settlement was first founded by Sturgiske colonists, who were allowed to explore the Ircaran lands in an alliance between the Sturgiske and the chieftain of Kurava.

Karalinna is the most isolated forest-fort of the Vakken. It lies on the edges of the Karakaz forest, far from the wars in the Calradian core lands. The Vakken have found little resistance in these cold forests surrounded by open plains and permafrost hills, up until the large scale migration of the Devsegs, now organized around the Khuzaits. Nevertheless, their distant position and fierce resistance of their sacred woodlands have kept them unsubdued so far.

Vanninlinna, or Vanni's fortress, is a forest fort of the Vakken. It is said in a distant past, a northern adventurer named Vanni settled with the Vakken tribes here. For his strength and justice, he was made chief. Today the Vanninen rule over Vanninlinna, and claim to be his descendants.

Ahankalat, the iron fortress, was founded by the Darshi in the lower hills of the Kohi Rohini. The fortress oversees an extensive mining operation. The soil here is crimson red due to its extensive iron richness, which the Darshi mine and send back to their cities. These hills, however, are also fertile and able to provide farmland and pastureland, a valued resource around the Kohi Rohini.

Sahel on the far edges of the Aserai lands, on the low-lying Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of millet and wheat.

Ekur sits on a pass at the edges of the Kohi Rohini, where mountain streams converge and form a greenish vale. The Darshi, experts at making use of any fertile land they find, have long since settled the region. Once, this fortified town was a trading post with the Devseg, who occasionally wandered from the far east into the vales and passes around hte Kohi Rohini.

Quyaz was once a mercantile republic that dominated the trade between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea, speaking the now all-but-extinct Kannic tongue, a relative of Nahasawi. But imperial hegemony slowly snuffed out its trade, and the rulers was taken over by mercenaries from the Nahasa. It came intermittently under imperial subjugation but today is a prized holding of the Banu Hulyan, a leading clan of the Aserai sultanate.

Rod-Ha-Sray lies on the hills east of the Teyagh, where tributaries merge towards the sacred river. Its palace is detached from the city, surrounded by the waters and rock from all sides, making it exceptionally hard to conquer. Many a Sharab who ruled from this palace felt confident to question their Shah.

The port of Sanala is the gateway through which the grain of the lower Damar has flowed forth to feed a hungry world. The Empire's periodic advances south of the Perassic Sea have usually been aimed at seizing this strategic prize. Although the legions were long ago forced to retreat, Sanala remains among the most cosmopolitan cities in Calradia, filled with merchants from many lands bidding for the lowest bulk prices.
Esi Noog
Tubilis lies on the Bay of Charas, which the Aserai call Shariz. Villagers go fishing here amid the offshore islands in search of tuna, sardines, and shark.
Kul Kojir
Mudu Iliwgul
Koir Ju

Shuron is a fortified town of the Kannic, at the very tip of where the Nahasa touches the ocean. Originally a fishing hamlet, it now guards the last of the Kannic, beaten by the Nahawasi and Calradoi. Shuron lies by the sea, folks farm dates, raise sheep by the hills, but mostly catch fish.

Fanab sits in a low promontory between the bay that the Aserai call the Gulf of Shariz and the inner sea of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The seawinds bring just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.
Zaharra Gero Hiria
Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Gavys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.
Jauregi Herria
Arrantzale Herrixka
Gazdreo i Gondh

Lageta was infamously acquired by the Empire by an act of treachery. A rogue imperial mercenary murdered the Palaic chieftain who employed him, took the citadel, invited in imperial colonists, then bequeathed the town to the Empire. The Senate disavowed his action but accepted the bequest. The district is now thoroughly Calradicized, but the Battanians to the north remember, and whenever an imperial envoy speaks of the sanctity of treaties and pacts, they just nod to each other and say, 'Lageta.'
Varagos Castle
Varagos sits on the Aris river, a small highland stream that flows into the deep pool known as the Ophthys. The land here is not especially rich, but is sufficient for the raising of sheep.

Limnon is a fortified settlement by the shores of lake Lakonis. It was once a city-state of the Lakonioi, who allied themselves with the Calradoi in their struggle against the Palaicoi. For their willingness to welcome the Calradoi, there was no bloodshed once the imperial dragons flew over the town walls. The town is today thoroughly Calradicized, and the port on the placid waters of the Lakonis take in ships of the Sturgiski laden with fur.
Lochana sits on the eastern shore of Lake Laconis. The muddy, low-lying land here is well suited to the growing of flax.
Rhesos Castle
Rhesos sits in a plateau in the Dryatic mountains. Highland cattle thrive on the grasses of the heights.
Gaos Castle
Gaos sits in a broad valley in the Myzead, the hill country in the east of the empire. Nomadic herders once occupied this land, and the village's name is taken from their word for cattle.

Nevyarela, erected between Saneopa and Argoron, was long ago founded by the Lakonioi. Often, the Lakonioi would violently clash with the Palaicoi, who inhabited the mountains both east and west of the Lakonioi plains. Once the Calradoi came, the Lakonioi were quick to ally them, and eventually be completely assimilated.
Atrion in the valley of the Nevys, a cold, slow-moving river that drains into Lake Laconis. The level, wet land here is fine for the growing of flax.
Ari Kastron

Ari Kastron was built by the Aris river, overlooking a valley that goes deep into Dryatic terriroty. The Kastron acted as a base of operations to legions subduing the Dryaticoi tribes, a deed that always costed them much blood. Today the fortified town watches over silver and cattle settlements, who occasionally are harassed by small warbands. Moreover, with the dismantling of the Empire, the kastron controls a narrow passage between the northern and western empire factions, which is also the main, safest route between both realms. Today the kastron is considered to have much strategic value.
Ataconia sits on a plateau in the piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. The people of this area are skilled at finding seams of silver ore exposed by the streams rushing down from the mountains.
Ponum Kastron

Ponum Kastron is one of the most important fortifications of the Calradoi northern border. The fortified settlement guards the land bridges to the Sturgiske realm, as well as the northernmost connection to the Devseg plateau. With the dismantling of the Imperium, both foreign threats now seek to prey upon the infighting Calradoi.

Epinosa lies in the far north of the Empire, just south of the glacial lakes known as the Iltan portages, where ships are hauled between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis. The region is relatively thinly populated, but large herds of cattle graze on the green downs.

Pons is one of the northernmost settlements of the Empire. It is named for the 'crossing' of the Iltan portages, a network of glacial lakes that allow ships to be hauled between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis. The region is relatively thinly populated, but large herds of cattle graze on the green downs.

Rodagora was once a fortified city-state of the Lakonioi, who embraced the Calradoi and accepted their rule. The city thrived before it fell to ruins, perhaps by the struggle between the Calradoi and the Darshi, who expanded their domain across the Tanaesis. Yet the Calradoi made sure to rebuild and populate the town, and it greatly served them in keeping the Devseglar across the river. Rodagora protects iron mines and wood harvesting areas, essential to fuel the military engine of the fortification.
Syratos at the base of an escarpment just north of Lake Tanaesis. Villagers mine the hills above them, where cold winters crack the stone to reveal fine seams of iron ore.
Tememos lies in heavily wooded hill country at the northern end of Lake Tanaesis. Many of the villagers work as foresters, harvesting oak, beech and pine for the sale to the lake cities.
Galchaea Kastron

Mecalovea sits overlooking the Galchasic Cataracts, a series of rapids and waterfalls through which the Miron river empties into Lake Laconis. The village, perched on a cliffside for protection from raiders in this frontier region, thrives on the ore deposits exposed where the cataract cuts through the escaparment.

Agalmon sits near the juncture of the Galchas and the Miron, two small but fast-flowing northern rivers. This foresting village has had mostly good relations with its Sturgian neighbors thanks to decades of intermarriage, though they have become strained of late with the outbreak of war.

Epicrotea, the 'All-Conquering' was named after the eccentric long-haired military genius Sarapios, who crushed a Battanian host and secured the lands west of Lake Laconis for the Empire. Its towers, overlooking the Miron river, have frequently been a northerner's first glimpse of the awesome and terrible force to their south.

Marathea lies on a narrow shelf of land between the Miron river and Mount Aracathos, the tallest peak in the Dryatic mountains. The villagers are skilled miners, extracting iron ores from the nearby cliffside.

Stathymos lies in a narrow valley beneath a towering ridge of the Dryatic mountains. The highland streams wash fertile soil down the hillsides, making this district one of the breadbaskets of the imperial north.
Gymos is a quiet fishing village in the Diathmic Bay, on the far west of Lake Laconis. Villagers harvest pike from the bay's deep waters.
Dyopalis lies in a valley in the Dryatic mountains. Despite the cold winters, the region's fertile soils make this district one of the breadbaskets of the northern Empire.

Diathma, the city of the Divine Decree, was erected by an imperial general on the ruins of a Dryatic shrine overlooking Lake Laconis. It was the last stand of the Dryatics, the northernmost of the Palaic peoples, who rebelled against the Empire and were overcome. According to legend they were pushed back into the shallows of the lake and fought until they were exhausted and the bloody waters engulfed them.
Alosea lies near the entrance of the Diathmic Bay, on the far western end of Lake Laconis. The folk of this region live well off the pike and sturgeon of the lake.
Jeracos sits in meadowland in the northern piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. The climate, kept mild by the lake breezes, makes for good horse breeding.

Leukys sits in meadowland in the northern piedmont of the Dryatic mountains. Here the Calradoi started the exploration of the Dryatic limestone, necessary for them to settle into the region with permanent garrisons.
Masangara sits on the banks of the Nevys, a cold, slow-moving river that empties into Lake Laconis. Cattle are raised here in former marshy woodlands, now drained and turned into meadows.

Saneopa sits on a low pass leading from the Nevys valley to the north to the pool of the Ophthys. The ancient Palaic peoples of this region, like the Battanians, treated lakes as sacred sites, and the Ophthys in particular was said to be a gateway to another world. The hustle and bustle of Saneopa, one of the main trading centers of inland Calradia, stands in sharp contrast to the dark and silent waters below.

Enoisa sits by the shores of the Ophthys, the eye, a deep lake in the hill country south of the Dryatic mountains. Wheat grows here, fed by the ample rains of the north. Legend has it that this was once a shrine of the ancient Palaic people, who believed the lake was a gateway to another world.

Aeoria sits in the fertile Vale of the Aris, in the heartland of the Empire. The dialect here is laced with words from Palaic, the language spoken in the center of the continent before the Empire came.
Crios lies nestled amid the limestone ridges of the eastern Dryatic mountains. The highland soils make fine grazing for horses.
Calcys lies nestled amid the limestone ridges of the eastern Dryatic mountains. The Calradoi collect the limestone here, necessary to settle the mountains occupied by barbarians.

The city of Argoron sits where the cold, slow moving Nevys River meets Lake Laconis. This was once the land of the Laconians, who saw the Empire as a protector against the more warlike Palaic peoples. They welcomed and intermarried with imperial settlers and their chiefs joined the Senate, and their old language and customs faded away.

Potamis sits in a valley in the lower Dryatic mountains. The people of these parts have raised cattle since pre-Calradic times, and its milk and butter are sought out by traders and travellers passing through the region.

Alatys lies on the flat southern end of Lake Laconis, on delta lowlands formed by the River Nevys. The waters of the lake, which are very shallow and muddy here, are well-stocked with flounder and crayfish, while trout can be fished in the Nevys upstream.
Nortanisa is a fishing village on the southern shores of Lake Laconis. Villagers plac nets and cages in the shallow edges of the lake to catch roach, bream, perch, and crayfish.

Hetania sits beneath a spur on the far northeastern bend of the Dryatic mountains. As in many villages around here, the foresters of this region still speak the Palaic languages of the tribes who lived here before the Empire came.

Myzea gives its name to the Myzeiad, the rich hill country of the east-central empire. This region is the old stomping grounds of the senator Litos, who brought the Palaic tribes here into the empire relatively peacefully by offering them protection against raiders from the steppes. When he fell afoul of his rivals in the Senate, however, he tried to organize them into a rival 'barbarian' republic modelled on the ancient Calradian version. The empire snuffed it out, but the people here, now thoroughly Calradicized, still harbor an attachment to the old republican system and its partisans.

Vealos sits in the slowly rising eastern slopes of the Dryatic mountains in the eastern reaches of the Empire. Although mostly covered with beech and oak woods, the mountain slopes provide good grazing for horses and has traditionally been home to stud farms for the imperial cavalry.

Orthra, a relatively recent settlement, was named by an imperial captain after the dawn for its fine eastward views of the Myzead, the hill country of the eastern empire. It was founded as a stud farm to breed imperial horses with steppe stock from the east, and continues to provide horses for the imperial cavalry.

Myzeonix sits on the slopes of the Myzeiad. Good stone from the Myzeaid rocks gather here, which the Calradoi started collected at the time of Litos, as the newly annexed Myzea required the touch of civilization through expert marble masonry.
Themys lies under a ridge of limestone crags in the Myzead, the hill country of the imperial heartland. The grasses on the rolling downs are well-suited to the raising of sheep.

Samatha sits upon a sloping ridge in the sun-drenched highlands of the Myzead. The hillsides have been terraced to allow the growing of mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested, placed in vats and fed to silkworms.

Amprela is the foremost town of the far northeast of the Empire. Watchmen stand atop its towers, looking out for beacons from the frontier fortresses to the north, east and west that might signal the approach of raiders. Horse archers recruited from the rough Eleftheroi freemen drink in the barracks, waiting for the order to ride out against horsemen from the steppe. Cataphracts sally through its gates to vie with the princes of Sturgia for control of the trade crossing the nearby network of lakes known as the Iltan portages.

Avasinton sits in the wilder eastern reaches of the Myzead, the hill country of the central empire. Villagers have cleared away the thickets and thornbrush of this region, including the pungent wormwood after which the village is named, to allow the growing of mulberry bushes, the leaves of which are harvested and fed to silkworms.

Boreagora lies in the cold north of the Empire, by the network of glacial lakes known as the portages of Iltan. Nearby imperial forts, looming over the waterways, keep watch for Sturgian and Khuzait raiders. The lowlands here are suited to the growing of flax.
Nova Lysiapalis

Nova Lysiapalis lies on the western shores of the Empire. This fortified polis once patrolled the bay of Charasea, the Calradoi capital. Now, it lies somewhat forgotten, in comparison to its former importance, as the Calradoi fight their internecine, far away from the old capital.

Garontor gives its name to the promontory between the Gulf of Charas and the inland Perassic sea. Coastal meadows, where tall grasses tolerant of the ocean salt-spray thrive, support the rearing of fine horses.

Ariopalis is built near a steep ridge in the Aris valley. This favourable defensive position allows them to only worry about attackers from one side. From this position, they oversee and protect the numerous grain farms in their immediate vicinity.

Thorios sits in the Aris valley in the heart of Calradia. River irrigation and the relatively warm inland climate ensure that the grain fields of this district, along with neighboring Bergum, feed much of the central empire.

Bergum sits in the Aris valley in the heart of Calradia. River irrigation and the relatively warm inland climate ensure that the grain fields of this district, along with neighboring Thorios, feed much of the central empire.

Iltaramea lies on the northern shores of the Perassic. Imperial citizens enjoy a warm southern wind. Ships oft travel back and forth from the Geroiako isles, at times laden with slaves. Iltaramea was founded by the Calradoi, watching over a gap of the Iltaric hills that connects the Perassic to Poros and the imperial heartlands. At one point, southern raiders would come ashore here, traverse the forest and hills in secret, until they found the peaceful farmlands of the interior, hopelessly undefended.
Onica lies on the northern shores of the Perassic sea. The hills of this district are terraced with the olive groves for which the southern Empire is famous, producing a light, fragrant oil.
Thractorae Castle

Thractorae sits on a small bay that feeds into the larger Gulf of Charas. These lands, stirred by hot winds from the south and watered by hillside springs, have been used by imperial landowners for the experimental growing of date palms.
Veron Castle

Veron in the foothills of the Uchalion massif, near the headwaters of the Garys river. On summer nights the hills above the village are dotted with the fires of shepherds, taking their animals to graze on the upland pastures.
Goleryn sits in the warm, oak-covered Epiric hills, near both the Vlandian and Battanian frontiers. Sheep-raising is a way of life in these parts, as is sheep-rustling.

Erythryarea lies at the base of the mount Erithrys, sacred to the Calradoi. Because of this sanctity, the Calradoi have not further urbanized the mount, instead keeping watch for the Battaneid, who often delve into the deep woods that surround the mount. Erythryarea itself lies on a patch of open plains, surrounded by farms, olive and grape plantations the Calradoi carved out of the woods.
Hertogea lies in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a huge basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. Villagers grow olives on the slopes leading up the mountain.

Ortysiulapalis lies on the eastern shores of the Bay of Ortysia. This fortified town oversees Calradoi settlements in a small, green peninsula, separated from the mainland by a mountain range. Due to the presence of Ortysia, its naval trade relevance is little. For this reason, folks have adopted the name 'Little Ortysia' for their polis.

Oristocorys sits on the Bay of Ortysia, part of the seaway between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea. Early morning sea-mists from the west and the hot sun of midday allow the growing of wine grapes.
Elvania sits on the Bay of Ortysia, part of the seaway between the western ocean and the Perassic Sea. Olive trees grow on the slopes of the nearby hills, warmed by the southern sun.
Caerulon Kastron

Gersegos sits in the gorges of the Miron river, as it cuts between the cliffs of the Cursion Escarpment and the Dryatic mountains. Villagers have sunk mines into a spur that overlooks the village, extracting silver and other precious metals.

Montos sits at the base of the Cursion escarpment, near the Battanian frontier. The foresters here keep a watchful eye on their neighbors, always looking for raiding parties coming westward from the valley of the Miron river to their east.
Nideon sits on a low-lying meander of the Zeos river, in the shadow of the plutonic Mount Erithrys. Flax grows in fields reclaimed from the river marshlands.

Zeonica sits by the seaside at the base of the Iltaric hills, a land of wine, grain and horses. It was named for the Lady Zeona, one of the few women to rule the Empire - admittedly as regent for her son rather than Empress Regnant. It is known for the Zeonic Wind, a gale that blows northward across the Perassic Sea every summer carrying the burning heat of the Nahasa desert to the imperial south. In other seasons the weather here is mild, a weather pattern that has provided many a poet with a metaphor for the transience of passion.
Tarcutis sits on the shores of the Perassic sea. The sandy soil and morning mists, channeled by offshore islands, allows the growing of grapes overlooking the beaches.
Neocorys, the new village, sits in gently sloping land in the Temea valley cleared only recently of forest. The local landowners have established stud farms, supplying horses to the imperial cavalry.
Alsasos sits in the west end of the Temea, a broad valley north of the Perassic sea. Though the climate is relatively dry here, artesian wells allow farmers to grow bountiful crops of wheat.
Zeocorys at the foot of the Ilataric hills, running along the southern coast of the Empire. Though the climate is relatively dry here, artesian wells allow farmers to grow bountiful crops of wheat.

Every realm has a city whose inhabitants are mocked for their provincial unsophistication, and for the Empire that city was Jalmarys. One of the first imperial colonies established inland of the Perassic Sea, it served the Empire as a base to subdue the western Palaic tribes. Paravenos was happy to accept the plunder and slaves sent to them from its garrison, but snickered at them behind their backs. That changed when the Jalmaryan general Carsos staged a military coup. When a senator, stymied by his thick accent, nervously asked him to repeat a decree, he unsheathed his sword and said, 'Do you understand this?'
Gamardan sits at the head of a small bay that branches off the larger Gulf of Charas. The wines of this region are unusually sweet and strong, and valued throughout the Empire.

Aegosca sits at the head of the Temea, a broad valley in southern Calradia. Though named for the goats that used to roam this region, the landowners have turned over the pastures to the raising of far more profitable horses.
Dradios sits by the Lesser Amynis, a tributary stream of the Aminys river that rushes down from the heights above. Villagers divert the mountain streams to irrigate their rich grainfields.

Ortysia, named for the quails who inhabit the nearby coastal marshes, was the first Calradian colony on the shores of the Perassic Sea. In its early centuries, it fell under the authority of the Kannic city-state of Quyaz, but the empire's expansion soon united the colony with its mother republic. For centuries, sailors coming from the pirate-infested islands of the Bay of Charas gave thanks when they saw its towers looming through the haze of the western Perassic, signalling a return to safe imperial-patrolled waters.

Arpotis sits on a high bluff overlooking the confluences of the Aminys, Gavys and Zeos rivers. The sides of the hills are terraced to grow wheat, with cisterns to catch the rain blowing up from the sea.
Lysia gives its name to the narrow strait where the Perassic Sea joins the western ocean. It lies just on the Perassic side of the straits, near broad beaches that allow the farming of salt.
Vinela sits beneath the waterfalls where the Aminys river rushes down to join the Perassic Sea. Villagers collect salt from the sea in the shadow of coastal cliffs.
Garengolia lies near a rich vein of silver in hills overlooking the Gavys river. The Empire have minted its denars from these mines for centuries.

The Palaic chieftain of Amitatys had a particularly grim reputation, a tyrant who slaughtered innocents to appease the gods of the underworld in the hope they would grant him immortality. Inevitably, he fell into conflict with the Empire, and during the siege an earthquake crumbled his walls and allowed imperial troops into the city. More died in the ensuing sack than the tyrant had ever killed, but it was war, and the outcome - attributed to the wrath of Heaven - was a staple of imperial propaganda as they expanded their foothold in the region.
Elipa sits near the upper reaches of the Aris valley. These sunny, well-watered highlands are one of the breadbaskets of the Empire.
Phasos sits amid rolling chalk hills between the Temea and Aris valleys. The rich grass of the down is some of the best horse-breeding land in the Empire.
Péthra
Péthra lies next to the mountains that shield Amitatys. Villagers here gather stone from the mountain base, much needed for Calradoi infrastructure.

Rhotae is a former Palaic hill-fort in the shadow of the basalt slab of Mount Erithrys, once known as Rotash. It fell to the Empire shortly afer Lageta. The Palaic chief here, when he heard of what happened to his neighbor, slaughtered a dozen imperial citizens under his protection. The eccentric long-haired general Sarapios led the punitive column that took Rotash and burned it to the ground. 'Lageta we took treacherously but with little bloodshed. Rotash we took honorably, with great bloodshed,' he supposedly said afterwards. 'Both will be remembered as a stain on our name. The victor always takes the blame, but keeps the gold.'
Carphenion lies in the wooded highlands between the great basalt slab of Mount Erithrys and the Dryatic mountains. The villagers raise cattle in the highland pastures.

Vathea sits high on the slopes of the Dryatic mountains, facing across the valley to the great basalt slab of Mount Erithrys. The villagers mine iron from shafts sunk deep into the cliffs of the mountains.
Thersenion sits in the upper Aminys valley, in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a great basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. This district is one of the grain breadbaskets of the Empire.
Leblenion lies alongside the Aminys river in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a great basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. This district is one of the grain breadbaskets of the Empire.

Kalsaropalis is a small Calradoi fortified town next to the Calsa river. Mostly isolated from main trade routes, folks here live a relatively quiet life, making their humble livelihoods while buffered from the fronts of war. Trade goods, such as grain and hardwood, are shipped downriver to Danustica and beyond.

Odrysa lies on the far eastern frontiers of the Empire, just across the River Tiagys from lands that are now the Khuzait Khanate. Though this area is dry, oak and other trees grow in the Tiagys gorges and other nooks in the hills, sustaining a small lumber industry.

Tanaesisfinis lies at the crossing between the Tanaesis lake and the Tyagis river. The fortified town watches over the crossing to Transtanaesia, an old Imperial province now occupied by the Khuzaits. The town is also important for control of the river trade downstream, towards Danustica and the Darshi.

Corenia is one of the farthest flung villages of the empire to speak the Calradic tongue. It sits in the plains southeast of Lake Tanaesis in the shadow of the Akkan Hills, beyond which is spoken only Darshi and the languages of the steppe. Villagers grow grain here, keeping watch for raiders from across the frontiers.

Metachia is the lies on the southern shores of Lake Tanaesis in the frontier lands beyond River Tiagys. This imperial colony, established in more peaceful times, is a center for mulberry bushes used in silk production.
Melion Castle

Melion in a narrow valley near the center of the Myzead, a rugged plateau in the east of the Empire. Villagers here cultivate mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested and fed to silkworks, producing thread much valued by both refined imperial nobles for their courtwear and hard-riding nomads and frontiersmen, who wear it beneath their armor as an extra layer of protection against arrows.

Sagolina sits at the foot of a narrow valley in the Myzead, a rugged plateau in eastern Calradia. The silver mined from nearby hills helps explain the effort and expense to which the Empire has gone in past centuries to conquer and defend these lands.
Lavenia Castle

Ethemisa sits on the river that the Aserai call the Nahr al-Kals, the Bitter River, and what imperial citizens call the Calsa. Here, the river has just descended from the coastal hills and has not yet reached the alkali plains of the southeast. The lands around produce a fine crop of grain.

Gorsethyarea is a fortified town of the Calradoi. The garrison here mainly watches over the river, which once used to be the main pathway of southern raiders towards Calradoi heartlands. Ample fresh water and arable fields make the citizens of Gorsethyarea mostly unpreoccupied, if not for occasional levies to serve in the southern and eastern fronts.
Morenia sits overlooking the Sethys river, on a low pass leading over the hills to the valley of the Lycarea. Villagers collect clay from the riverbanks for the kilns of the imperial southlands.
Sestadaim Castle

Sestadaim sits on the western side of the great Ornian rock, an outcrop in the center of the Lycarea valley. Some say the vultures for which the rock is named once gathered here to feast on the bodies of those who died working the local silver mines.
Jogurys Castle

Jogurys lies on the flat western shores of Lake Tanaesis. This land was originally inhabited by nomadic tribes and has come under cultivation only recently. Imperial colonists have made intensive efforts to grow mullberry bushes here to raise silkworms, a lucrative product in this region.
Chanopsis Castle
Chanopsis sits near the headwaters of the Sethys river in the plateau region known as the Myzead. Wheat grows well on the sun-baked plains.

The frontier city of Danustica dominates the network of lakes and lagoons known as the Calsea. It has long held the line against incursions by the Aserai and various Darshi shahs and padishahs further to the east. Many an imperial legionary stationed here has scribbled graffiti on its walls cursing the city's sweltering summers, brackish water and the mosquitos that rise from the Calsea, but the inhabitants are proud of their role as border defenders and mock the soldiers wilting in the heat around them.

Caira sits amid the network of rivers, lakes and lagoons known as the Calsea. Any further east, the land becomes alkaline and barren, but here the floodplains of the parallel Calsa and Tiagys rivers allow the growing of wheat.

Polisia sits among the network of rivers and lakes known as the Calsea near the Aserai borderlands. Villagers harvest salt from a lagoon to their west, a former inlet of the Perassic sea that was cut off by a sandspit. These lowlands are shunned by many others in Calradia, who find the air thick and fetid, but the inhabitants are proud of their role keeping watch on the Aserai.

Tegresos sits just north of the River Calsa, right before it enters the network of lakes, creeks and lagoons that form the borderlands with the Aserai. The inhabitants of this region have bred sheep that feed on marsh-grasses.

Erebulos lies by a lagoon that was formerly part of the Perassic Sea, closed by a recently formed sandspit. Villagers scoop clay from the creek-bottoms here, selling it to the pottery kilns of Danustica and other nearby towns.

Vostrum was founded by the Calradian mercenary Archacos, one of a number of rogue commanders who broke away from the empire during its expansion. Unlike some, who tried to reproduce the empire's republican heritage, he chose to rule as a god-king. His dynasty lasted for generations, until imperial troops overran it and smashed every haloed statue of Archacos and his successors into rubble. Even today, western and northern imperial senators accuse families from this region of being closet monarchists.

The village of Atphynia sits near the mouth of the Sethys river, just before it splits into three to form the valley known as Tripotamia. Villagers here have laid out salt pans near where the Sethys estuary joins the Perassic sea.
Gorcorys sits on the Gorea, the southernmost tributary of the Sethys river in the valley of Tripotamia. The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.
Avalyps sits near the headwaters of the River Calsa in the warm coastal hills of the southern Empire.The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.
Alision lies on the northern coast of the Perassic Sea. Though fishing is poor in these parts, villagers have constructed salt pans that stick far out into the shallow waters.

The town of Poros sits near the northern shores of the Perassic Sea. The warm rolling hills of these parts are well suited to the raising of sheep and horses. The herdsmen have a reputation for being proud and violent, but the nobles of the Leonipardes clan who rule this land are careful to respect their autonomy. Livestock rustling and blood feuds are common here, and it is said that the Leonipardes will never interfere unless invited by both parties, but when they do, their judgments will be obeyed by all.

Canoros sits in the flat southern reaches of the Lycarea plain. This land has been good horse country since even before the Empire came, furnishing the steeds of the Lycarean riders who routed several Calradian armies before their final defeat and absorption into the imperial cavalry.

Tevea sits where the plains of Lycarea slowly ascend to meet the base of the Ornian Rock. They raise sheeps on the slopes of this massive outcrop, named for the vultures who glare down from its heights onto the hazy flatlands below.
Zestea sits where the plains of Lycarea meet the coastal Iltaric hills. Sheep graze on the low slopes overlooking the hazy flatlands.

The natural fortress of Lycaron sits on a spur jutting out of the great Ornian rock. In the final years of the imperial conquest, the Palaic tribe here negotiated a peaceful federation with the empire, only to see their home seized by the rebel leader Gethuz. The ensuing siege was only the first of many that Lycaron would undergo in the ensuing centuries, as its nearby silver mines made it a prize for every imperial pretender who ever tried to seize power in a civil war. It is said that the colony of vultures who inhabit the upper reaches of the Rock have dined on the flesh of every people of Calradia.
Sagora on a low ridge in the middle of the Lycarean plain. This district is one of the rockier and less fertile parts of the plain, but the valley scrubs still supports the grazing of sheep.
Popsia in a narrow canyon between the Ornian Rock and the valley of the Ophthys pool. Trees grow tall here in the cool shadows of the hills, and villagers harvest pines for sale as lumber.

Canterion lies in the east of the Lycarean plain. The slowly rising land here gets more rain than other parts of the plain, and the rich grasses have made it good horse country since even before the coming of the Empire.

The tale of Sarpea of Onira is one of the epic poems of the eastern frontier. Like many, it seems written to justify the Empire's conquest. Sarpea, a senator's daughter, was seized by a Palaic chieftain and carried to his citadel here. When the imperial armies appeared before its walls years later to rescue her, she begged them to retreat for the sake of her infant son, whom her fearsome husband had threatened to hurl from the walls instead of allowing him to be captured and raised by his mother's people. The legions withdrew, so the story says, but the boy grew into a warrior who joined the Empire and slew his father. It is now the center of a horse-breeding industry on the eastern plains.

Lanthas in the broad plains south of Lake Tanaesis. This is good sheep country, but in a land scoured by imperial fugitives, wild Eleftheroi riders and steppe nomads, the villagers here have learned to watch their flocks closely.

Lartusys lies near the southern end of Lake Tanaesis. The village sits near a deposit of salt, and salt springs occasionally bubble to the surface, feeding the legend that this was once a gateway to a haunted underground sea.
Parasemnos sits close to a low pass linking the Tanaeitic plain with the valley of the Calsa river. The villagers collect wood from the ample woodlands.

Phycaon sits at the head of the Sethys valley, one of the main grain-producing regions of the central Empire. Once the largest of the Palaic cities, its leaders led a league of the tribes against imperial encroachment into the region. But when the empire's victory looked inevitable, they made their peace. The population, now thoroughly Calradicized, have a reputation for being serious, respectable and trade-minded, dependable if a bit humorless.

Saldannis lies beneath gypsum bluffs overlooking the River Sethys. The fine soil of the hills makes for a sticky clay when it washes down to the river, much prized by the potters of the imperial south.
Spotia lies alongside the gently flowing Sethys river. The low rolling hills of this district comprise one of the breadbaskets of the Empire.

Zethakma lies on a high plateau by the mountains next to the Sethys river. It is said the Palaicoi worshiped their gods here, until the peaceful annexation by the Calradoi. Ever since, the Calradoi moved in, and their expert masonry made good use of the stone deposits available. Over time, the Palacoi gods were forgotten.
Amycon lies in a series of small but sharp ridges between the Ornion Rock and the Aris valley. The people of this land are sheep herders, known for their dry, salty cheese flavored with cumin.

Next to Ornosos, the Ornion rock a high plateau, unfit for growth of greens. Here rich marble is deposited, and the Calradoi were quick to find and make use of it to build their temples, villas and statues.

Syronea sits on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis. This city, once peaceful and rich, was once a byword for luxury and decadence. This was the center of the Empire's silk industry and an entrepot for the goods flowing in from what was known as Transtanaesia, the imperial possessions and protectorates beyond the great lake. But the coming of the Khuzaits ripped the Transtanaesia from the Empire's grasp and the Senatorial families of Syronea were forced to relearn the arts of war, dusting off old gilded armors and sharpening bejewelled swords to lead their followers against Urkhun's warriors.
Psotai sits near the southern tip of Lake Tanaesis. The low-lying fields here are one of the major grain producing centers of the eastern frontier regions.
Vargornis is a fishing village on Lake Tanaesis. Huge pike can sometimes be found in the lake's waters, along with more common perch and bream.
Eunalica sits on the western shores of Lake Tanaesis. This low-lying country is fine land for the growing of flax.

Kongard is the westernmost fortification of the Sturgiske, nearly at the tip of the Kachyar peninsula. Though the valleys here are strait and the rocky soil is not very fertile, people here still thrive on fishing and herding. Being at the tip of the peninsula, Kongard is a prime destination for Jumne ships, be them peaceful or otherwise.

Ustokol sits on the windswept Kachyar peninsula, between the Bay of Varcheg and the Byalic Sea. Hardy northern cattle have been bred to eat the short grasses that grow among the rocks, supplemented by sea-kelp in hard times.

Zelenopol oversees the mountain passes between the core Sturgian lands and the eastern most edge of Tyal, the realm of the Vagiroving. The settlement first started as a trading outpost for the furs of the Vakken, who mainly occupy the northern woods.
Mazhadan sits near the source of the Galchas river, just west of Lake Laconis. Villagers grow flax in the muddy valleys between the hills in this cold, rainy land.
Nevyansk Castle
Nevyansk sits on a flat shelf of land overlooking the Bay of Varcheg. The land is cold, but the runoff from the hills brings rich soil, and villagers grow hardy crops like rye and barley.
Dnin sits on pastures overlooking the narrowest part of the Bay of Varcheg. Horses graze on the heights, glancing down occasionally at the trading longships and fishing boats passing beneath them.

Ismilkorg sits on grassy downs between the Galcha and Vastra rivers, two small tributaries of the Miron. The people here are mostly cattle-herders as well as cattle-rustlers, and have long traded raids with the imperial frontier villages to the east and Battanians to the west.

Ov is a recent Sturgian colony in the Ircara wilds, a forest northwest of Lake Laconis. Villagers brave cold, wolves and the sometimes-hostile, sometimes-friendly peoples of the woods in pursuit of fur, the bounty of the northlands.

Ferkh lies at the northern edge of the Ircara wildlands, a forest northwest of Lake Laconis. It serves as a base for traders venturing deeper into the woods, brave cold, wolves and the sometimes-hostile, sometimes-friendly peoples of the woods in pursuit of fur, the bounty of the northlands.

Takor is a cattle raising village at the pass that the Battanians call Mynad Rhyfel, the mountain of war, and their imperial and Sturgian neighbors call Minador. It is one of the main trading and raiding routes between the wild north and the more settled imperial lands.

Urikshal oversees the very end of the Byal sea, neighboring the Sturgian town of Tyal. It is said a great warrior by the name of Urik came here with a host of his followers, and proclaimed the land his own. Local rulers, still of Jumne ancestry, claim to be his descendants. For the most part, the inhabitants of Urikshal prefer to trade and farm, but still hone their axes for war.

Urikskala sits in the Portages of Iltan, a network of glacial lakes over which longships can be hauled and sailed between lakes Laconis and Tanaesis. Villagers net small spiny perch and crayfish in the shallow waters, drying them for sale to travellers.

Iltaborg lies on the hills that overlook the Iltan lakes. The fortified town oversees the lowlands of mount Iltan, where the Sturgians, at times mixed with Jumne, have settled for cattle raising and foresting. The Iltan lakes provide a natural layer of protection from southern invasions, specially from the Calradoi, and the few land passes are patrolled by Sturgian riders. Folks here find special joy in the smooth, crystal blue surface of the lake.

Vladiv sits at the base of Mount Iltan, in a cold, dark wooded valley. The hardy cattle of this region have learned to dig through thick winter snows in search of grass to sustain them until the spring.

Rodobas, the house of Obas, is named for a long-dead Sturgian hill chieftain. Perched high on a ridge overlooking the wilds of Ircara, it serves as a base for trappers looking for furs in the dark woods below,
Forin sits among rye and barley fields next to the Galcha river, on the edge of the Ircara wilds. The village thrives on the grain it sells to the woodland fur-trapping communities.

Kargrev was once Car Gryff, the ringfort of the Battanian chief Gryff, but was conquered by the Sturgians two generations ago. It lies alongside the Bay of Varcheg, where the local fishermen take advantage of the relatively sheltered waters of the bay, where fish of many kinds come to spawn.

Balgard, which sits on the icy waters of Mazopor bay, was founded by migrants from the Nordlands. Legend holds that the initial wave of Nords arrogantly demanded tribute from the nearby Vakken and Sturgian tribes, who formed an alliance and drove the newcomers back to their ships. But the victors fell out over the spoils, until a canny Nord, Gundar, landed and volunteered to help them fairly divvy up the weapons and armor of his dead kinsmen. The residents recognized Gundar's lordship over the region and his descendants, intermarried with the Sturgians, are today the grand princes of Sturgia.
Safna sits on a high ridge overlooking the rapids that link Lake Laconis to the narrow Mazopor Bay. Villagers rear cattle on the grassy shelfs overlooking the sea-cliffs.
Marabrot sits on a high rocky ridge between the fjord known as Mazopor Bay and the Byalic Sea. This harsh land would probably not be settled where it not for the rich iron deposits in the hills.
Kamydorg is halfway between Balgard and Kongard. Villagers here quarry from the steep valley walls, naturally rich in stone.

Dvorusta is a fishing village overlooking the rapids linking the Bay of Varcheg with Lake Laconis. Villagers make their way down the cliffsides at dawn to catch salmon leaping over the rocks, as well as herring and cod in the sea.

Omor sits on the eastern shores of Lake Laconis. Long before the Sturgians formed themselves into a principality it was a holy site for the forest tribes, who worshipped their gods and ancestors in the sacred oak trees of the nearby woods. Today, it is an emporium for fur trappers and woodsmen who prowl the Ircara wildlands to the east, and the primeval peace of the forests is drowned out by the sounds of bartering, saws, and the unloading of ships at the lake.

Chornobas, or Blackwood, sits in lands cleared from the forests overlooking the cataract through which the Miron river empties into Lake Laconis. The villagers grow rye and barley in fields misted by the spray from the falls.

Skorin sits on a promontory separating Dyatom Bay from the wider Lake Laconis. Villagers pull both freshwater flatfish from the shallow bay waters and bigger catch, including pike, from the main lake.

Varnovapol, which sits beneath the Chertyg mountains on the crystal waters of Lake Laconis, has the dubious honor of being perhaps the most-often conquered city in Calradia. Originally it was a colony of the Empire, infamous as a place of exile for dissident senators, before it was seized by Nords as a base to expand their influence into the Sturgian fur trade. It was taken by the Alkit tribe from the eastern steppe and briefly served as the capital of a small khanate, before finally falling to the fierce Ormidoving clan.

Borchovagorka sits on a small rise on the steep northern shores of Lake Laconis. The village depends primarily on fishing, pulling perch, bream, salmon and occasionally large sturgeon and pike from the lake waters.
Glavstrom sits beneath Mount Iltan, a craggy peak in eastern Calradia named for a god of the steppe peoples. These wild lands abound with fur-bearing marten, fox, rabbits and other animals.

Omkany lies where the Lake Laconis coastline rises up to meet the icy Chertyg mountains. Villagers in this district raise hogs, curing their fat with salt and in garlic and selling it throughout the northlands.
Yangutum sits in a nook of the Chertyg mountains on the north shores of Lake Laconis. Villagers here have found iron ore deposits in the mountainsides.

Tyal sits in the western foothills of Mount Iltan, on the eastern borders of the Sturgian lands. This region has long stood aloof from the power struggles of the other Sturgian principalities. Its people are known as wanderers, traders, horse breeders and fur-trappers. The local aristocracy has occasionally exchanged princesses with the steppe tribes to the east to firm up a truce or a trade pact, and proudly includes the names of several great khans on their list of ancestors.

Visibrot is a sheep-rearing village on the lower slopes of Mount Iltan, just below the network of glacial lakes known as the Iltan portages. Though this region is cold and remote, its importance as a trade juncture between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis, between the Empire and the steppe, mean that it is relatively densely populated.
Bukits sits on the eastern slopes of Mount Iltan on the Khuzait frontier. Villagers raise highland cattle here, bred to withstand the icy gusts that tear down the mountain.

Alov sits on the edge of the glacial lakes known as the Iltan portages. Villagers cultivate rye and barley on the high ground overlooking the lakes, and the rich black soil of the region compensates for the long winters and short growing season.

Sibir was founded in a dark valley amid the Chertyg mountains by Nordic traders, who wished a base to buy furs from the local Vakken-speaking foresters. As the Sturgian tribes became principalities, and elected chieftains evolved into boyars who demanded taxes and labor as their due, this region became a magnet for Sturgians who had little taste for deference. Today, the ambitious Isyaroving family governs this region, but they must always balance their hunger for wealth and men to fight their wars with their subjects' reluctance to provide it.

The villagers of Kvol raise small, sturdy cattle at the base of the Chertyg mountains. They include the descendants of refugees and malcontents from across Calradia, seeking isolation in the cold northern forests.
Radakmed sits in a basin amid the Chertyg mountains. Villagers here grow flax in the marshy valley floor.

Alebat sits deep in the forests of northeastern Sturgia. This isolated region has long been a refuge for those fleeing oppression or debt or bloodfeud across the northlands, and the dialect is strongly influenced by the tongue of the Vanni woodspeople.

Revyl, chief town of the rocky Kachyar peninsula, was a traditional rival of Balgard. According to legend the Balgardian princess Arkina, whose husband had been slain by the Revylians, accepted a proposal from her enemy's king to marry and settle the feud. On her wedding night, however, she barred the door of his hall and burned him and a hundred of his kinsmen and warriors alive inside. The feud has long since been settled by pacts and marriages with happier outcomes, although Revylians still resent the ascent of the Balgardian Gundaroving dynasty.
Korsyas sits near the narrowest part of the Bay of Varcheg. Villagers fish the waters to the west for cod, char, and other cold-water sea fish that venture into the bay.
Karbur sits at a plateau on the Kachyar peninsula. Sheltered somewhat by a high ridge to their north, the villagers here raise barley and grain.

Zhemyan is a fishing village at the northern shores of the Kachyar peninsula. Villagers brave the storms that sweep through the Byalic Sea to pull up ample catches of cod, char, and sometimes even small whales.

Hasirit lies on the fertile highlands of the Jabal Ashabi mountains. The exploration of grain farming here is ancient, and very valuable in this otherwise desert region. To the south, the Darshi have mastered their own patch of highland, making great open farms near Urukur. Hasirit was once under their influence, but now the fortification serves the Nahasawi.

Asmait lies in a nook of the Jabal Ashabi mountains, bordered to the south by the deep desert. Villagers trap floods running down the hills during rare rainstorms, using the water to grow date palms and other crops.
Bawwabat Balad

Bawwabat Balad is a fortified town that lies next to the Damar river, with its back covered by one of the many escarpments of the Jarjara. The riverbank provides towns folk with ample farmingland, allowing full food independece for the town.
Ain Baliq

Ain Baliq is clustered around a well in a wide valley that separates the Jarjara Escarpment from the Jabal Tamar mountains to the west. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.
Deir Hawa
Deir Hawa sits on the windswept southern shores of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. Villagers trap run-off water from the hills and grow flax in the lowlands here.
Wahah Balad
Wahahbalad lies next to a major, pristine oasis close by the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The access to fresh water and good farmland make it an obvious choice for settlement.

Medeni sits in lowlands between the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers grow dates by the coast in gardens watered by wells and small dams in the wadis that trap run-off from the cliffs during the short rainy season.

Qidnar lies in the floodplain of the Damar river, the most densely populated part of the Aserai lands, where it slices through the Jarjara Escarpment. Farmers here grow grain in the rich silt brought by the river's annual flooding.

Long ago founded by the Kannic, Memab, the rock by the sea, lies in the fertile valley of Qasira. As the legend tells, the great queen Eshora made the valley flourished with her magic, which she used to control the Jinn, spirits of nature, according to the Kannic. Memab protects the easternmost entry of this valley, much valued for its fertility. In typical Kannic tradition, even after the Nahasawi occupation, folks here maintain a naval custom.
Jamayeh sits on the southern shores of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al Yeshm, the Jade Sea. The climate is well-suited to olive trees that thrive despite the short rainy season.

Gadirits is one of the most ancient colonies of the Kannic. Unlike most, it lies inland, guarding the land pass between the Kannic, mainland Calradia to the north and the Darshi riverlands to the southeast. Many a time the walls of Gadirits were besieged, specially once the Calradoi came, never allowing it to fully thrive into a metropolis. Its walls now serve the Nahasawi, who in their ambition betrayed the Calradoi and carved themselves a kingdom out of the southern provinces.
Shibal Zumr

Shibal Zumr sits on the Nahr al-Kals, the river of lime. Here the waters are pure and the soil is fertile, and grain is grown. But a short distance to the south, the land becomes barren and alkaline, and only the hardiest crops survive.

Shurelit, named after the Kannic goddess, lies on the rockfase of the westernmost escarpements of the Nahasa. Unlike most Kannic colonies, this fortified town lies high on the hills rather than on the shores of the Perassic. Here the plateau is rich in fresh water from the rock, allowing fruit, olives and sheep to thrive. Shurelit also guards the land connection between Quyaz and the rest of the Nahasa, long ago defending it from desert raiders.
Uqba sits alongside the Perassic Sea. Villagers trap rainwater and runoff from the hills to water their fields and their gardens of date-palms.

Bunqaz sits at the mouth of the great wadi that divides the Jarjara Escarpment from the Jabal Tamar hills. Villagers sink wells here to tap the wadi's groundwater, using it to irrigate their olive groves.

Surh, the Rock, is a fortified town on a rocky promontory. It was firstly a colony of the Kannic. Old supertitions say that jinn spirits inhabit the forests near Surh. To this day, the Nahawasi, despite their faith differences, still remain distant from the forest depths. As of Kannic tradition, the town has ease of access to the sea and continues a strong naval tradition.
Tamnuh sits near a large lagoon, cut off from the Perassic Sea by a sandspit. Villagers scrape clay from the shallow waters to sell to the region's potters.
Damar Balad
The oasis-village of Barihal sits in a wadi amid the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. The land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.
Tasheba lies on the western edges of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Fishermen venture out into the protected waters, gentle and calm for most of the year, for tuna and sardines.
Baq slightly inland from the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, beneath the great granite outcrop of the Jabal Tamar. The seawinds bring the uplands here just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.
Hiblet sits at the base of the granite outcrop known as the Jabal Tamar. Rainwater trapped in cracks in the rock is diverted to the village's date-palm gardens.
Husn Fulq

Husn Fulq sits at the southeastern edge of the Caldea, the network of rivers and brackish lagoons linking the Empire to the Aserai lands. Fulq, also known as Phalcos, was a dark-faced mercenary chieftain who came from lands far to the south. He founded a fortress here and then parlayed its strategic location into a fortune, taking bribes from the Empire and then from the Aserai to switch sides. After 20 years of playing both sides back and forth he sailed home in a ship laden with gold, but many clans of the Aserai proudly claim descent from him, and the 'Tricks of Fulq' are a staple of many a bazaar storyteller's repetoire.
Lamesa sits amid open plains and patches of dry acacia forest on the eastern shores of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Some of the Aserai's most prized horses graze on the grasses of this district.
Abu Khih

Abu Khih sits along the Nahr al-Kals river on its way to its barren southern reaches. The surrounding lands, an ancient lakebed, are already becoming barren and alkaline, although date-palms still thrive.

Hoqqa sits on the far east of the Aserai lands, on the Tiyagis river. The land is mostly desert-steppe. Barren most of the year except for scrub, it is covered in grass and flowers in the spring and is fine grazing for horses.

Iyakis sits in a cleft in the Jarjara escarpment, where the waters of the fierce but brief desert rains can be trapped and used for irrigation. For generations ago it was an autonomous outpost of the Empire known as Yachios, dominated by the Carasios clan. Fifty years ago however they saw the writing on the wall for imperial dominion in the southlands, and began intermarrying themselves with the tribes of the Nahasa. Today, known as the Qaraz, they take their places in the councils of the sultanate like any other family of the Aserai.

Abba sits on the edge of the deep desert, at the foot of the landward side of the Jarjara Escarpment. Runoff from the hills is trapped underground here, creating springs that sustain an oasis. Wheat thrives in the fields and gardens.

Hunab lies in one of the wadis that cut beneath the weathered mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers raise horses here, taking advantage of the brief but lush crop of grass that covers the slopes in the spring.
Bir Seif
Bir Seif is centered around a group of wells and pools in the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers dig down to the shallow groundwater layer for clay to sell to the potters of the Nahasa.

Razih is said to be the base from which Kannic explorers set forth to colonize the shores of the Perassic Sea in the centuries before the coming of the empire, the prows of their ships decorated with the intertwined vine leaves of the Kannic goddess of wealth, wine, love and war. Today, the Kannic tongue has been replaced by Nahasawi dialects and their religion is all but forgotten, but the symbol lives on, said to protect those who risk all for the sake of gain or glory.
Qablab sits near a broad bay on the southern coast of the Perassic Sea. The low-lying coastline is well-suited to the construction of salt pans.

Mussum sits near the eastern coast of the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, where the Aserai deserts give way to desert-steppe with scattered acacia and scrub. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.
Labanabn lies on the desert-steppe mountains near Razih. Rich deposits here allow the extraction of pristine, white marble. The Kannic were the first to settle here, expert masons since eras past.

Kuqa sits at the foot of a range of low hills east of the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, where the Aserai deserts give way to desert-steppe with scattered acacia and scrub. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.

Doqa is a fishing village on the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. Villagers sail out in feluccas to harvest perch that sometimes grow as long as a man is tall, keeping an eye out for the salt-water crocodiles which live in the local inlets and marshes and which compete with them for their catch.

The inland city of Hubyar is said to be built on the ruins of a luxurious hunting lodge built by the decadent and cruel king Thuran, whom the patriarch Asera slew in vengeance for the enslavement of his family. This memory may explain the worldview of the fierce and austere Banu Qild, who hold the castle today and who detest all frivolity. But the scent of jasmine that can be detected on the night breezes here carries an undercurrent of temptation. It was here that the hero Nimr came to grief, caught in the chamber of a Banu Qild maiden and left hanging in a cage in the market until he perished.

Mahloul sits in a broad valley between the Jarjara Escarpment and the Jabal Ashab hills in the desert steppe southeast of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Groundwater provides just enough water to grow crops for subsistence, while the village makes its money from rearing horses on the rich grass that grows in the Jabal Ashabi after the spring rains.
Liwas sits in a broad valley south of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Farmland is limited here, and the land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.
Waltas sits by the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea, in lowlands well suited to the growing of flax.
Mijayit lies off of the estuary of the Damar river as it reaches the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The rich silt deposits left by the river make this one of the most fertile regions of the Aserai lands.
Hamoshawat lies on the lower Damar river, just before it reaches the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The rich silt deposits left by the river make this one of the most fertile regions of the Aserai lands.
Jahasim sits on the southern shore of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. The warm waters abound in tuna, bonito, sardines, and other fish.
Nahlan sits on the floodplain of the Damar River as it cuts through the Jarjara escarpment. This soil, refreshed yearly by the silt of the flooding river, produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Askar dominates the middle stretches of the Damar River, as it weaves between the bluffs of the Jarjara Escarpment. This region has been thickly populated for thousands of years, but the river is restless, and every few centuries leaps its banks and erases what comes before. This latest regional capital was an imperial encampment during their furthest penetration of the Nahasa several centuries ago, taken over by the Aserai tribes after the legions withdrew.

Wadar sits in the rocky wadis at the inland edge of the Jarjara Escarpment, before it gives way to barren gravel plains and dunes. Clouds from the Bahr al-Yeshm drop their last reserves of water here in the spring and winter, giving the land just enough grass to support horse-rearing.
Bait Hatif
Bait Hatif sits in the floodplain of the Damar river as it cuts through the Jarjara Escarpment. Rocky soil in this district limits irrigation, but horses thrive on the spring grasses of the hills.
Mabwaz overlooks the Damar River as it weaves through the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers grow wheat and other crops in the silt of the river floodplain.

Zalm sits at the Scorched Gates, where the Damar river descends from the Nahasa desert and starts its journey through the Jarjara Escarpment. The silt brought by the river produces bountiful crops of wheat.

The legendary Queen Eshora, it is said, punished the jinn who were harassing her people by imprisoning them in one of the caves above Qasira, carving the mystical eight-pointed star into the rock to seal them in. She sentenced them to haul water from the depths of the earth, feeding the springs that gush forth from the rocks and which for centuries have irrigated the date gardens of Qasira and its surrounding villages.
Ezbet Nahul

Ezbet Nahul sits on a rocky shelf overlooking the waters that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Groundwater trapped by the rocks is accessed by wells and used to irrigate the village wheatfields.

Aigoisinaman, the city by the holy water, is where the Siri first gathered. Here, it is said, Laha Mouei gathered his pride, on a rocky promontory by the Aman, and declared the land his terriroty. The Siri claim to be descendants from that pride.
Etu Koir
Kul Nokajor
Esi Koir

Dawidipp was founded long ago by the Siri, after the founding of Aigoisinaman. Dawidipp eventually outgrew Aigoisinaman and became the power base of the Siri queens, despite its sister city being the center of the faith. Countless caravans pass through and by Dawidipp, up and down the Aman, and the flow of trade feeds the city much like the riverbanks of the Aman.
Irk Kojir
Irk Uun
Esi Ju
Kappa Kipti
Abghan sits by a small lagoon on the southern shores of the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Villagers here fish for tuna, sardines, bonito and shark.

Epirend, though an old Calradoi colony, never thrived as its sister colony, Charasea. Epirend, at the time known as Epirea, was first build to fortify the eastern gulf of Charasea from the Battaneid raids. Despite the rich iron and wood of the region, folks never liked moving towards the 'front', and instead preferred the relative safety of Charasea and its island cruising ships.
Usanc sits by a small bay that flows into the larger Gulf of Charas. This warm southern land supports the growing of olive trees.

Beorgas lies in the woods south of the Etir river, past the mountain pass. It was first settled by the Calradoi, but by the time of the Wilunding invasion, it was mostly abandoned. The Wilunding have since repopulated it, and their truce with the Battaneid, though unpredictable, has freed the community from raids.

Rodepir lies at the base of the Epiric hills. The Calradoi first started the exploration of ores centuries ago, along the entire stretch of the hills. The mining here has been continued by the Wilunding.
