Biscanend was once a Calradoi settlement. The mountain passes near Biscanend were the first path of the Calradoi northwards, eventually towards Paravenos. To this day, it oversees the Trand river as well as the bountiful forests between the Biscan hills and Sonotorea, now called Sunor by the Wilunding.
Hongard sits in the warm wooded lands near the meandering Trand river. This land, rich in wheat and once the heartland of the Empire, is now the center of the Vlandian kingdom.
Ferton near a curve of the meandering Trand river, not far from a pass leading seaward over the Biscan Hills. The villagers grow olives on the warm, dry landward side of the hills.

Valsden was likely built on top of an existing Calradoi fortification. It is said that here the warlord Valan built his hall, felling nearby forests and bringing their wood up the promontory by the sea. For he knew this good land would thrive with grains and horses. According to the Wilunding, Valan destroyed the Calradoi hosts sent to stop him by turning into a wolf - a werwulf, they call him.
Drapand sits near the tip of Cape Fal, a promontory just south of the mouth of the Trand River. The villagers venture out far into the seas to cod-rich banks washed by a cold current from the north.

Orbur is a recent Wilunding settlement, situated near the river Or, as well as the bay of Ostican. The bur, a fortified settlement, protects the narrow pass between the Wilunding heartlands and the Ebor peninsula, whose control is increasingly in the hands of the aggressively conquering Jumne.
Ormanfard sits by a small, fast-flowing river that runs down from the mountains of the Rhennod to fill the lake known as Ocspool. Rains are plentiful and wheat and barley grow well on the hillsides.

Calsbur is an ancient Calradoi Kastrum, built at the times of the old Sargot in order the control the inner bay and the easy crossing by boat to the Kachyar peninsula. Its name derives from the Calradoi 'Caleus', a bastardization of the old Battanian hillfort, which the Calradoi conquered and expanded upon. It now serves the Jumne invaders, who have conquered the northern Wilunding settlements, and frequently receives Sturgian traders.
Caleus lies on the misty coastal plain south of the Bay of Varcheg. Villagers speak a mix of the Vlandian, Sturgian and Battanian tongues. They grow flax in the lowlands here.
Deriat sits between the Bay of Varcheg and the ridges of the Ebor peninsula. Villagers here trap beaver and mink in the hills and sometimes pursue seals in the waters of the bay.

Eanstweox lies between the Trand and Etir rivers. Here the Wilunding erected this fortification in order to protect the iron supply of Rodetan, and the path northwards towards Ocshall. Folks here trade by boats both down and upriver, when the Battaneid are not hostile.
Talivel in the middle of the Trand valley in the heartland of Calradia. Villagers plant olives here on the hillsides.
Ocs Hreth

Ocs Hreth lies at the top of the valleys between Ocspool and the old Sonotorea. It was once the hill-fort of a Battanian chieftain, defeated by Oca and his followers. Though this fort already existed, its slopes were unfit for a large settlement required for Oca's tribe, and thus Ocs Hall was founded after the seizure of the hill-fort. Ocs Hreth stands for Oca's triumpth, for both the original inhabitants and their name for this land were forsaken.
Verecsand sits by the waters of the Ocspool, a small but deep inland lake. Villagers here grow wheat in the gentle downs by the lakeside.

Porthmerea was long ago built the Calradoi next to their major colony, Charasea. The port was meant to both fortify their presence in the nearby Gulf of Charasea and Strait of Lys, as well as expand their settlement and influence on the peninsula. Its ancient walls were destroied by sieges and raids, both by the Jumne raiders, attacking from the sea, and the Wilunding, conquering from the land. Now occupied by the Wilunding, Pordmer serves as a country baron's seat, rather than an important Imperial wharf.

Merbec sits by the coast of the Gulf of Charas, in its promontory of reddish soil. Long ago the Calradoi started fishing from this promontory, a good trade in the rich warm waters. The Wilunding now continue this tradition.
Balanend lies at the southernmost tip of the Gulf of Charas coastline. Here palm trees grow with the hot climate, and the Calradoi long ago started farming these fruits.

First used to pay the ancient legions, Pisaman's salt has long been explored by the Calradoi. Sitting of a small promontory of reddish, salty soil, villagers here continue the tradition, though salt is not nearly as valuable as it once was.

Belocatharea was once at the forefront of the struggle between the Calradoi and the Battaniaid. Here the legions were resupplied - importantly, with wine - such that they could climb the slopes towards the Uchalion plateau. Their struggle was fruitless, for even if any gains were made, they could not be held against the highland tribes. Belocatharea was likely founded on top of an existing tribe. Nevertheless, the Calradoi could never allow the existance of a divergent culture within their heartlands. Much like the remaining Western hemisphere, Belocatharea fell to the Wilunding hosts, and most of the city was populated the the Rhodok tribe: a double-edged 'award' by the Osrickin, for they could tell the city could easily fall to the highland tribes, if they were to come down on them.
Calioc on a flat plain between the Epiric and Biscan hills of the central Vlandian lands. The people of this district grow flax on the marshy lands.

Etirfurd sits near the Battanian frontier on a low spur just west of where the Etir river comes bursting out of a spring in the cliffs of the Uchalion massif. The villagers here grow wheat, finding a ready market in the garrisons stationed nearby.
Rodetan takes its name from the ruddy, iron-rich soil of this part of the the Rhennod hills. The mines of this district supply the iron ore for many of the forges of the Vlandian kingdom.
Ocs Hall

Ocs Hall is one of the few towns in the Vlandian kingdom that was founded after the seizure of the land from the Empire. This valley was once an isolated holdout of Battanians, centered on the Llyn Modris, a lake in a volcanic caldera that was said to be the seat of a giant. This land was conquered by the Vlandian warlord Oca, who also gave his name to the nearby Ocspool lake. The Battanian tribes were driven inland, and took their legends with them.
Mareiven sits on the steep wooded slopes of the Rhennod mountains, overlooking the Ocspool. Villagers harvest the tall trees of the heights, selling the logs to cities on the coast.

Oritan sits on a short river that rushes out of the mountains of the Ebor peninsula and empties into the Ocspool. The river slows as it hits a nearby bend, allowing the collection of potters' clay from the banks.
Fregian sits on the flatlands north of Pravend, where the warmth of the Vlandian south begins to give way to the chills of the north. Villagers plant flax here amid the bogs and pastures.
Marin lies on the slopes west of the Ocspool. Misty mornings cooled by sea drifting south and warm afternoons make this land well-suited to the growing of grapes.

Sonotorea was the last colony founded by Calradios. It ensured that the Calradoi would have a firm grasp of the inland path towards their new, bustling city: Parzeonerea. At such time, local tribes still roamed the Trand valley, including those that preceded the current Battaniaid. Much like Parzeonerea, its name honored its founder: Sonotorea, the city of the deliverer, for it was Calradios that delivered newfound freedom to the exiles he brought alongside him. The city was among the first to fall to the Wilunding, who put great value on the plains guarded by the city, abundant in grains and steeds.
Valanby sits overlooking the Trand estuary. Villagers plant flax in land reclaimed from the riverside marshes.
Rulund sits in the forested middle valleys of the Trand. The villagers specialize in the raising of hogs, who feast on acorns from the oak woodlands.
Larnac sits on gentle hills on the lower Trand valley. Villagers plant rye, barley and wheat for sale to the hungry urban population of nearby Pravend.
Palisont sits at the mouth of a rocky glen that splits the grassy downs north of the Trand river. The soil is thin in these parts, but the village does well farming hogs and other livestock.

Galend overlooks the wave-beaten Biscan coast. It takes in the catch from the Biscan's intrepid fishermen who venture out far into the western ocean, as well as the wool of sheep from the green fog-covered hills. The current line of Vlandian kings comes from the clans who settled in this region during Osric Iron-Arm's invasion.
Furbec sits on a shelf overlooking the rocky Biscan coast of central Vlandia. The climate is warm most of the year, and grapes do well on the slopes of the Biscan hills.

Meroc is a fishing village overlooking a cove in the Biscan Coast. The villagers sail out into the western ocean in search of mullet and bass near the shore, and tuna and sardines amid the islands to the south.
Nogrent sits on a slope of the Biscan hills in central Vlandia. Villagers here raise sheep on the pastures between the coastal woods and the high crags of the hills.

Jaculan sits in the warmer southern reaches of the Biscan coast, in rolling hills known for their olive trees. It was once a favored resort of the imperial aristocracy, who hunted wild boars amid the oak forests. The independent peasantry of this region are known for their heterodox ideas. The Brotherhood of the Woods is but the latest of a series of rebellions to have broken out here, sometimes aided by an aristocracy that considers them a tool to use against rival Vlandian houses.
Arromanc lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills. The warm lands of the Vlandian south are well-suited to the growing of olives.
Mot lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills. The warm lands of the Vlandian south are well-suited to the growing of olives.
Alorstan sits on a shelf overlooking the sea, at the foot of the Biscan Hills. The warm south of the Vlandian lands is well-suited to the cultivation of olives.
Chornad sits overlooking a pass through the Biscan hills. The villagers of this region, like many in the central Vlandian kingdom, specializing in the raising of pigs.

The city known today as Charas is traditionally reckoned to be the first Calradian colony on the shores of their new continent. At the Empire's height, when the capital moved north to Paravenos, Charasea remained a key hub of sea-faring and trade, while imperial aristocrats built their summer homes on the warm shores of the nearby gulf and cruised their pleasure-boats around its islands. When the Vlandians came, Charas fell into the hands of the ruthless House of dey Cortain, and its wealth funds their ambitions.
Savinth sits on warm, grassy plains north of the Bay of Charas. The land is fine pasture for the renowned horses of the Vlandians.
The village of Vesin lies by a creek running down from the Epiric Hills to the Bay of Charas. This warm land is well-suited to the growing of olive trees.
Silexinth sits by the southern base of the lower Biscan mountains. The Calradoi long have gathered stone from the mountain faces, and the Wilunding have continued this tradition here.

Paravenos was the second major colony founded by Calradios the Great, and it soon succeeded Charasea as the capital of the Calradoi. It was known as Parzeonerea - City of He Who Rules By Heaven's Will - in honor of its divine founder. Eventually, the empire's center of gravity moved east, but Paravenos retained its primacy as the economic center of the West. When Osric Iron-Arm the Vlandian invaded, he recognized Paravenos would be far more valuable as a seat of power than as simply as a source of loot, and negotiated its surrender with local senators. It passed to a cadet branch of Osric's line, the dey Tihr clan, and is today known as Pravend.

Dyrring lies at the heart of the Trand valley: a flat, rich valley fertilized by the major Trand river. Here the flat fields with ease access to the river make the valley perfect for growing grains. Dyrring was once a Calradoi settlement, and fed much of the Western hemisphere of the Imperium. Unlike Pravend, the city resisted the Wilunding occupation, leading to its slaughter and rampant destruction. Nevertheless, the Wilunding rebuilt much of walls now with wood, such that they too can control this bread basket.
Os Share
Os Share lies on the fertile plains of the Trand valley. It was once inhabited by the Calradoi, but now the Wilunding farm these lands.
Burhlane lies on the fertile plains of the Trand valley.

Sargot was founded on the ruins of an imperial town, Sargythea, now resettled by Vlandians, and which has supplanted the memory of the community that came before it. Sargythea was founded to become a trade hub for northern furs, fish and whale, not only with the Sturgians but with the Junme. The Calradoi called this bay the Bay of Whales, now known as the Bay of Varcheg. However, maintaining the polis proved difficult with the complex logistics, nearby Battanians, Junme raiders and later Wilunding settlement cutting off the route to the rest of the Empire.

Horsger is where, according to legend, the warrior Horsa came ashore and planted his spear in the beach. Today it is known for its daring fishermen, who venture out far to find banks, chilled by currents from the north, that are rich in cod.
Cananc lies in the wet wooded hills of the northern Rhennod, where cedars grow tall in the sea-mists. The villagers trap beaver, marten and rabbit for their pelts.

Remental sits in a gap in the mountains of the Ebor peninsula. Towering fir and spruce grow on the slopes. Villagers trap fur-bearing animals like marten, rabbit and fox. This wild region has recently attracted many settlers drawn to the relative freedom of the woods, where the rule of the Vlandian barons is much lighter than in the south.

Ostican was a minor imperial port that became a haven for seafarers of the northern oceans. Many were talented corsairs, employed by imperial factions to harry their foes during the latter empire's intermittent civil wars. Indeed, the some of the first Vlandians to come to Calradia's shores settled in the back alleys of this town, and no doubt sent word to their kinsmen of the riches to be had here should anyone invade in earnest.

Cananc lies in the wet wooded hills of the northern Rhennod, where cedars grow tall in the sea-mists. The villagers here collect limestone from the hillsides. This tradition first began when the Calradoi attempted to expand into the peninsula, and thus required stone for their walls, roads and aqueducts.

Rovalatys, in the mountains of the Ebor peninsula, was never fully an imperial town. Nordic migrants, drawn to the region by rumors of riches to be made prospecting for silver or hunting for furs, long outnumbered Calradians even before the Vlandian invasion. The Vlandians too recognized its potential, and despite its harsh winters this land is among the more populous regions of the kingdom, with bountiful fields in the valleys of the mountains feeding the constant flow of settlers from the south drawn here by their hunger for wealth.
Alantas sits in the center of the mountainous Ebor peninsula. The soil here is thin and the weather here is cold, but rich iron deposits sustain the local economy.
Halisvust was once a marshy wasteland, but Vlandian settlers drained the waters and sowed wheat and rye in the valley.
Car Etireid

Car Etir lies on a hill by the Etir river, overlooking lush, green plains. It was first settled long ago as a small chieftain's ringfort. Now a fortified town, it watches over the main route between the Wilunding and the Battaneid. Lately, these relations have been mostly neutral, focused on trade. However, the Battaneid know to not trust the Wilunding ambition, for they have carved themselves out of the Empire, who they first pretended to be friends with.
Ab Comer
Pen Balasog

Car Balasog is a small fortified town by the Glen of Balasog, its back facing a mountain ridge. Folks collect water from the mountain streams, harvest grape from the hillsides and grain from the green plains in front of the town. Car Balasog watches over both valleys that lead into the Wilunding and Calradoi territories.
Llanoc Hen

Llanoc Hen sits in a ridge in the heights of the Uchalion massif. The villagers, known as skilled pig-farmers, look down two passes, the western one leading up from Vlandian lands and the eastern one leading up from the Empire.

Cantrec sits in the rocky Glen of Balasog that climbs up from the imperial lands into the plateau of the Uchafion. The lands is not especially fertile here, but pigs thrive in the bush and shrubland of the heights.

The rock by the sea, Dunmor oversees the Morcomb valley. This small town is a recent Battaneid settlement. For a long time, the Morcomb valley was a region of contention between the Battaneid and the Calradoi, and later with the Wilunding. However, with both great powers losing Sargot, the Battaneid were able to secure the valley and its silver.
Druimmor sits in the Morcomb, a rift valley that divides the Uchalion plateau from the mountains of the Ebor peninsula. Miners here have found silver in clefts in the hillsides.
Pendraic Castle

Pendraic sits on the steep northern slope of the Uchalion, facing the Bay of Varcheg. It is a land of cold winds and constant low-level warfare, cris-crossed by Vlandian, Battanian and Sturgian raiding parties. The villagers raise hogs here, always listening to the warning horns telling them to drive their herds to hiding spots in the hills.
Car Myreid

Rhemtoil lies beneath a cleft in the eastern escarpment of the Uchalion plateau, near the source of the river Miron, which the Battanians call the Myr. This is among the most fertile of the Battanian lands, and produces a fine crop of wheat.
Claig Ban
Claig Ban lies at the foot of a steep cleft that climbs the Uchalion massif. The villagers here gather clay from the nearby Myr river for sale to the potters of the Battanian towns.
Car Cafalcombe

Car Cafalcombe sits on the base of the Cafalcombe valley, which connects the Battaneid and Calradoi realms. The town is built against the mountains for extra protection and water access, and is surrounded by fertile plains.
Flintolg sits on a high crest on the eastern side of the Uchalion massif. The soil is poor but the woods grow thick here, making this the source of much of the timber used in the Battanian lands.

Glintor sits overlooking the rapids of the Fiur river, where the waters of Llyn Tywal descend to enter the Bay of Varcheg. Horses are raised on the downs, much prized by both raiders and traders from the Sturgian lands to the north.
Pen Mon

Pen Mon, or Mon's Hill, is a fortified town that lies on top of a rocky hill, called Dun by the Battaneid. This hill lies next to another, Dun of Glanys. Pen Mon was long ago settled by one of the many Battaneid tribes, and is said to be Mon's throne. The town watches over surrounding pastures, farms and woodlands. In the olden days, it was certainly a powerful seat from which to project power, for the tribes fought each other more than foreign, common enemies.

Aster sits in a shallow valley between the hills of the northeastern Uchalion and the Rock of Glanys. The people of this region have the reputation of being more focused on trade than warfare, and tribal elders have encouraged the cultivation of mulberry bushes to sustain a small silk industry.
Car Vaseid

Uthelaim sits on the eastern frontiers of the Battanian lands on a ridge overlooking a tributary of the Myr. The people of these parts are foresters, felling the oak, yew and pine of the woods for sale to builders and shipwrights.

Marunath, the 'Horse of the Ford,' is nowhere near a river. But Battanian bards love nothing more than an incongruous place-name around which a legend can be woven. In this case the hero Ochlaigan, who was foretold to defeat the seven sons of Glanys in seven duels near seven fords, encountered the last of his enemies here. He slit his horse's throat and crossed over the stream of blood that gushed forth, defeating his last enemy and fulfiling the prophecy.
Dalmengus sits by the side of the Llyn Tywal, the Dark Lake at the center of the Uchalion massif. The flat, well-watered lands here are fertile and well-suited to wheat and barley.
Ebereth sits on a saddle, with the lake of Llyn Tywal on one side and the passes of the Cafalcombe on the other. Villagers here grow grapes to make the sweet white wine of the Battanian lands.
Beglomuar sits in a nook of the southern escarpment of the Uchalion massif. There is little to recommend these lands other than the ore deposits in the hills and the bog-iron of the mountain marshes.

Llech sits in a nook of the southern escarpment of the Uchalion massif. The Battaneid extract the stone deposit here, increasingly important to fortify their walls against the growing threats from all directions.
Ath Cafal
Ath Cafal sits near the head of the Cafalcombe, a steep valley that descends to the imperial lands. Decent clay can be found in the small streams that rush down from the hills on all sides.

Dunglanys, the 'Rock of Glanys', stands on a high crag overlooking the Llyn Tywal, the pool of darkness at the heart of the Battanian lands. It was named after a ancient queen who, legend has it, married in succession five high kings of Battania, bestowing sovereignty upon them. It is the center of the rituals that underpin Battanian kingship, and though not every Battanian high king has ruled from here, all are eager to hold it.

Diantogmail sits on the edge of Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. There are a half-dozen local legends explaining how the region got its name, which means the 'Flight of the Stoat,' but no two of them match in any particulars. Villagers here grow grapes for wine.

Glenlithrig, the valley of the slippery stream, lies in the highlands of the northern Uchalion. The villagers here are primarily foresters, supplying timber to the nearby fortress-towns of Dunglanys and Car Banseth.
Morihig sits in a basin in the middle of the Uchalion massif. The region is known for its production of wheat and barley.
Imlagh lies on rolling downs in the middle of the Uchalion massif. The village specializes in white grapes for the making of the sweet Battanian wines.
Lindorn sits on the green hills north and west of Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. The surrounding farmlands are sown with wheat and barley.
Car Banseth

Car Banseth sits high on the cliffs of Ailta Druin. Staring north on a clear day, across lands that were once Battanian but are now held by the Sturgians and Vlandians, one can see the waters of the Bay of Varcheg. It is said that those who keep faith will one day witness from this high point the ships of the vanished High King Mon, who shall return to deliver his people from their enemies. But today, one is far more likely to see the sails of Nordic adventurers and mercenaries, coming to assist the foreigners in their relentless push into Battanian land.
Bog Beth
Bog Beth sits in a low, forested valley in the east of the Uchalion massif. Villagers trap beavers, foxes and other fur-bearing animals in the dark, marshy woods.
Geunat Nal

Geunat Nal, the village where Nal left his head, is a fur-trapping village near the site of a duel famous in Battanian legend. The villagers are known for their skill as foresters, helping the nearby cliff-top fortress of Car Banseth to guard the northern approaches to the Battanian heartland from Sturgian and other raiders.
Tor Leiad

Tor Leiad, the hill of the full moon, lies beneath a wooded knoll in the northern Battanian lands. Villagers harvest the thick-growing forests of oak, yew and beech. The woods here have been tended carefully by the Battanians for centuries, ensuring that there are always enough trees to harvest and sell for timber.
Tor Melina
Tor Melina sits in a marshy basin in the dark forested hills of the northwestern Uchalion massif. Villagers take clay from the damp soil for sale to the potters of nearby towns.

Seonon, sad Seonon, has a history as dark as the waters of the Llyn Tywal. Here Algana the Fair stood atop the tower lamenting the death of her beloved Gorawan, until the spirits of the Otherworld were themselves overcome with sadness and allowed his shade to ascend through the pool for a day and a night to console her. In latter days this land has often been ravaged by Sturgian raiders, and not far from here lies the wood where King Aeril disappeared, clearing the way for the rise of Caladog.
Bryn Glas
Bryn Glas sits in a ridge in the eastern escarpment of the Uchalion massif. Villagers mine iron from the hills, for sale to the renowned smiths of nearby Seonon.
Andurn sits in a cleft in the hills overlooking Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. The villagers of these parts tend the forests, harvesting beech, oak and yew for sale to the towns.
Mag Arba
Mag Arba sits on grassy downs overlooking Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. Villagers have planted flax in the boggy dales between the hills.
Swenryn overlooks the rocky cataract that holds back the dark waters of the Llyn Tywal, creating the lake in the center of the Uchalion. Horses graze above the rapids and waterfalls.

Seordas sits in the lowlands at the eastern edge of the Battanian lands, at the foot of the Uchalion escarpment. The nearby fortress of Uthelaim shields the district's exposed farms from Sturgian raiders coming from the east.
Pen Cannoc

Pen Cannoc sits on a promontory overlooking the Trand river as it plunges from the Uchalion plateau into the Vlandian lowlands. Legends speak of the water-nymphs who live in the dark pools under the rock, luring travellers and invaders to their deaths, except on those rare occasions when they fall in love with a hero and grant him victory and blessings. Certainly the fisherfolk of this region have learned respect for the perils of the upper Trand, where a small misstep on slippery stone can cast one off a precipice into the waters below.

Durn sits just below the gorges of the upper Trand river. Villagers scrape mud from the pools and bogs alongside the river as it levels out, carting it up the winding paths to the town of Pen Cannoc perched on the cliff above them.
Gainseth sits in a dark wooded valley beneath the Rhennod hills on the eastern edge of the Uchalion massif. Villagers collect mud from the marshy ground for sale to the potters of Pen Cannoc.
Fenon Etir

Fenon Etir sits on an outrop overlooking the source of the Etir river, a tributary of the Trand. Villagers here raise grapes, producing strong Battanian wines that are highly valued in the Empire and among the Vlandians.

Inveth sits where the rivers Trand and Etir come tumbling out of the Uchalion massif, join together, and flow into the plains of central Vlandia. The surrounding hillsides support the growing of wheat.

Left unmaintained by the Darshi, Akakur was once ruled by them with a different name. The fortress is positioned to prevent Calradoi incursions into the core of the Devseg, where the Darshi have long fought to maintain control. The Khan's policies have moved many settlers here, most of which maintain a pastoral tradition.
The village of Esme and its surrounding hamlets lie on the landward side of the Akkan hills on the Devseg plateau, prime grazing lands for the flocks of the Khuzaits and their confederates.

Long ago erected by the Darshi, Sarozu oversees the mountain pass between Akkalat and Tanaesis, where the Calradoi and Darshi would often clash. Today it is governed by the eastern horselords, who garrison and maintain the fortress, highly important for their maintained influence and trade flow of the region.
Akiser sits in the southern reaches of the Akkan hills. The land here is exceptionally broken and weathered, revealing seams of iron in the sides of the gullies and ravines.

Sarak is a Darshi-founded fortified town on the Akkan hills. Named after its white soil, the hills are rich in minerals, for which the Darshi built this fortification. Its patrols protected supply caravans of silver and iron, bound to Akkalat and sent down the Obuz river towards the Darshi homelands. The town also harvests hardwood from the nearby forest - a valuable resource in these parts.

The village of Hakkun is perched atop the escarpment of the Akkan hills. The people of these parts have long mined silver from the mountains, a trade that the Khuzait khans were happy to encourage when they conquered this region.

Tepekur lies on the northern edge of the Devseg plateau, close to the Zakhan river. The fortified town, likely first erected by the Darshi, was found by the horselords abandoned. The Khan's policies have moved settlers to the town, whose inhabitants now descend almost all from the eastern nomads. Being on the northern edge of the Akkan hills, the fortress oversees a strategical position between the Devseg to the south, the Calradoi and Tanaesis to the west and the Iltanlar to the north.

Tepes sits overlooking a tributary of the Karakaz, a river that flows from the north into Lake Tanaz, which the Empire calls Tanaesis. This district specializes in the harvest of timber which is floated down the river and sold to the lake towns.

Sulankur lies at the base of the Sulan Daglar, the desert mountains. The moisture gathers in this region, allowing the growth of a forest. The Khan's policies have made many nomads settle here, permanently exploring its resources and paying the Khan tribute.

Khimli sits in a basin the Devseg plateau. Though this land is dry most of the year, it experiences winter snowfalls and muddy springs. Fine clay can be collected from the pools left by the snowmelt and the rains.

Karakhand, the black fortress, named after the black forests of pine found in the base of the Sulan Dag mountains. This fortified town was settled by the Iltanlar long before the eastern Devseg arrived on their horses. The Iltanlar make use of these fertile plains to raise fat sheep, one of their main food sources in their original land, the dry Sulan Dag.

Dinar lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, along the Karakaz river. Snow-bound for much of the year, the spring grasses nonetheless sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from this land's icy winds.

Karahalli lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, not far from the icy Byalic Sea. Snow-bound for much of the year, the spring grasses nonetheless sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from the icy winds blowing off of the waters.

The tale of the Lover's mountain, according to tradition, states a Darshi Shahpur, or prince, was to be betrothed to a foreign princess. Although both prince and princess desired their marriage, the Shahpur became preoccupied with a rebellion in his kingdom. Though the rebellion was crushed, the Shahpur discovered that, in the meanwhile, another man fell in love with his beloved princess: a famous sculptor, said to sculpt an statue so perfect, it looked like the princess in flesh herself. In order to quell his love-rival, the Shapur stated the sculptor shall have the princess' hand in marriage, if he can sculpt a fortress out of a mountain. And so the sculptor did, forging Hamdam out of stone. Rather than keeping his word, the Shapur sent false message to the scultor that the princess had passed away. Taken by sorrow, the sculptor launched himself from the mountain top, into the Tsanga Nor. Folks say his sorrowful spirit poisoned the water with salt. Nevertheless, the Shahpur, now elevated to Shah, secured another fortress to his dominion.
Simira sits near the east of the Devseg plateau, as it begins to descend into the great grass sea of the east. Villagers here raise cattle bred to withstand both cold winters and hot summer.

Sarrod is a Darshi town by the Teyagh river, which flows down to the Darshi homelands. This old colony makes use of the iron deposites by the river bank, as well as the ample grassland. The town now lies in control of the Devseg, who have cast away much of the Darshi ruling classes in and around the Devseg plateau. Nevertheless many subjects remain true to their ancestry, and were allowed to continue their livelihoods in exchange of tribute to the horselords.
Erzenur alongside the Tiagys river, known in the local dialect as the Teyagh. The waters here have a distinct reddish tint from the iron in the soil, which the villagers mine from riverside outcrops.
Sabze-Zur lies on the western side of the Teyagh. The Darshi made use of the green plains to grow crops, always so limited by the scarcity of watered lands in their country.

Morokhand is a fortified town built by the Iltanlar, next to the riverbanks of the Karakaz. It was often visited by the Sturgiske, who also settled in the area and brought their cattle raising traditions. For a long time, both tribes maintained good trade relations

Kaysar sits in the north and east of the lands ruled by the Khuzaits, in the valley of the Karakaz river. This district is snowbound for much of the year, but villagers still raise herds of cattle bred to withstand the icy winds coming downriver from the north.

Payam lies alongside the Karakaz river in the cold north of the Khuzait lands. Though the land is snowbound much of the year, the villagers sow wheat and barley as soon as the melt starts, taking in a good crop before the autumn.

Baltakhand, the Fortress of the Axe, was settled by the Iltanlar, mountain-dwelling cousins of the Khuzaits. Centuries ago their beys descended into the plains and created the fortress here that guards the portages of Iltan, the network of lakes and rivers that divides the Sturgian lands from the Khuzaits' realm. Bitter winters protected them from the reach of the Empire, but no blast of wind was cutting enough to stop the horsemen of Khan Urkhun, who 40 years ago forced this town to submit to the khanate.

Fisnar sits alongside the Zakhan, a tributary of the Karakaz river. Though this valley is snowbound for much of the year, the spring grasses nonetheless sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from this land's icy winds.
Ulaan sits in the valley of the Karakaz river. The villagers, nomads who have recently been forced by the khans to settle, have learned to grow flax in this low-lying marshy land.

Kuruluk sits alongside the Zakhan, a tributary of the Karakaz river. Though this valley is snowbound for much of the year, steppe ponies thrive on the spring grasses and in the winter dig through the snow for food, their thick coats protecting them from the icy blasts of wind.

Asalig sits at the foot of Bars Dag, one of the peaks that marks the edge of the Devseg plateau. Villagers raise horses in the lower slopes, keeping watch for the snow leopards for which the peak is named.

The town that the Khuzaits know as Akkalat, the White Fortress, was built by the fearsome Padishah Hoshtar on one of his periodic attempts to conquer the Devseg. For decades the sacred flame that burned from the top of the citadel symbolized his suzerainty over the tribes here. But the Padishah's realm like the Empire is on the defensive and has retreated to the east. Today the Khan's horsetail banners fly in its place.
Karakalat lies in a basin in the flat, eastern edges of the Devseg plateau. Until recently, this land was dominated by nomads, and it is still famous as a breeding ground for horses.

Tismil sits on the Ozu river, which drains the southern end of the Devseg plateau. The people of this land are sheep-herders, who have thrived under Khuzait overlordship as the khans keep nomadic raiders at bay.

Gereden and its outlying hamlets on the southern end of the Devseg plateau, near the juncture of Ozu and Teyagh rivers. Though rough country, it is known for the fine clay that can be gathered from the ravines.
Kiraz lies in a basin at the southern end of the Devseg plateau. Until recently, this land was dominated by nomads, and the people here still make their living by raising sheep.

Makeb sits on the northern tip of Lake Tanaesis, Tanaz in the steppe tongue. Here, it guards the cataract over which the Karakaz river empties into the lake. This city has long been ruled by petty khans and shahs, who collect tolls from traders forced to haul their boats around the rapids. The last of those rulers was beheaded by Urkhun himself after he refused a demand of tribute, after which the ruling family of the Khuzaits seized this town for themselves.
Shapeshte sits where the waters of the Zakhan river meet the Karakaz. The village makes its living from mining nearby salt deposits.
Hanekhy sits atop a northern spur of the Akkan hills. The reddish streaks in the soil and rocks testify to rich iron deposits, which are mined by the villagers.

The fishing village of Mazen sits on the northern end of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz sea. The villagers set nets in the nearby Karakaz river to catch a variety of fish migrating to and from the lake.

Ortongard sits in the dry center of the Devseg plateau, which is dry for most of the year but offers rich grazing in the spring. Founded by Darshi-speaking merchants, it made its wealth buying horses, sheep and cattle from the surrounding herding villages and sending them west to the markets of the empire in huge drives, accompanied by guards to ward off raiders from the steppes. Neither its walls nor its mercenary armies could withstand the coming of Khan Urkhun, however, who it granted to the Khergit clan in recognition of their valor.
Omrotok sits at the foot of the Sulun Dag mountains, that mark the eastern border of the Devseg plateau. Villagers go to the nearby woods to harvest one of the Devseg's few sources of timber.
Ransam in the southeastern plains of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, specialize in the rearing of horses.
Mivanjan sits at the foot of the Sulun Dag mountains, that mark the eastern border of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, raise sheep in the foothills.
Urunjan near the western edge of the Devseg plateau, at the foot of the Akkan hills. Villagers raise cattle here that are bred to withstand both the hot summers and freezing winters.

Chaikand sits by the reed-marshes on the edge of Lake Tanaesis. In the years when the east was an imperial protectorate, boats laden with hides, wool and salt shuttled across the lake's placid waters, returning with imperial silks and silver. With the coming of the Khuzaits and the subsequent wars the water-trade stopped, but Chaikand remains a major trade entrepot and military base, the fief of the ruling Urkhunait clan. From the pavilions of his palace, the khan can look out across the lake and see the hazy outline of hills that he may one day graze his horses upon.

Kamshar sits by the shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The fishing is poor in these parts but villagers collect clay from the lakeside for sale to the potters of Chaikhand and other towns.
Okhutan is a village at the center of a wheat-growing district on a narrow stretch of plain between the Akkan hills and Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea.
Ispantar is a village on a rocky spur of the Akkan hills overlooking Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers here make most of their income from the raising of sheep.
Pabastan sits in the narrow plain between the Akkan hills and Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. This land is fine country for wheat.

The town of Odokh sits at the foot of Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. Among the most remote of the towns of the Devseg, it is reputed to have been the abode of King Ahhak, a mythical tyrant from whose shoulders flowed serpents. Even today the Kohi Rohini has a reputation for black magic and mystery that helps keep outsiders at bay. The city fell during the Khuzait conquest to the Harfit clan, who have intermarried with the mountain peoples, and who honor their customs, participate in their rituals, and keep their secrets.

Karahan lies in in the foothills of the Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. The villagers here buy horses from the wandering tribes, and raise some of their own, making this the source for many of the steeds ridden by the Khuzait armies.
Nutyuk sits beneath the outcrop known by its Darshi name, the Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. The villagers here, mostly recently settled nomads, raise sheep like their ancestors.
Danara sits by the salt lake that the Khuzaits know as Tsanga Nor, the pool that quenches no thirst. The villagers of these parts extract salt from the bitter waters.

Sangsaran lies in in the foothills of the Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. The Darshi long ago started mining here the mountain slopes for stone, much needed for their high and thick city walls, and thus required for their expansion into the Devseg.
Kohi Ajik

Kohi Ajik lies in a narrow, dry valley at the foot of the so-called Lover's Mountain, from which its name derives. The peoples of this land buy horses from the nomads to their east and sell them to the Khuzait aristocracy in the towns.
Seaside Hideout
The Retreat
This is the retirement retreat location.
